latest news.eng_title: August 2024 Inflation Rate to be Announced by TÜİK
latest news.summary: The Turkish Statistical Institute (TÜİK) will announce the August 2024 inflation rate in the coming days. The inflation rate will affect various sectors, including rent increases and salary hikes in January. The inflation rate for August 2024 is expected to be announced on either Monday, September 2, 2024, or Tuesday, September 3, 2024, at 10:00 AM. According to the previous announcement, the annual inflation rate for July 2024 was 61.78% and the monthly inflation rate was 3.23%.
latest news.title: AĞUSTOS AYI ENFLASYON RAKAMLARI - Enflasyon oranı ne zaman, saat kaçta açıklanacak?

latest news.eng_title: The last time inflation was under 3% was March 2021
latest news.summary: The US inflation rate has dropped to 2.9%, the lowest it's been since March 2021. Economists like Sean Snaith and Carola Binder recall the economic changes and challenges of the past few years, including the pandemic, geopolitics, and staffing shortages. They discuss how the country's economy was 'roaring back to life' in 2021, fueled by low interest rates, rising home values, and stimulus checks, but ultimately led to a surge in inflation. The Fed raised interest rates 11 times to combat inflation, which peaked at 8.5% in 2022. Economists still debate whether inflation was transitory or not, but Betsey Stevenson believes it was, and that the key now is to find the right interest rate to keep jobs and the economy steady. 'I think that yes we got there,' Stevenson said. 'But, you know, we want to see the more sort of stable, sticking below 3%.'
latest news.title: The last time inflation was under 3% was March 2021

latest news.eng_title: Bank Employees to Receive 4% Salary Increase in August
latest news.summary: According to La Bancaria, the union that represents bank employees, the recent paritaria agreement in August 2024 will result in a 4% increase in salaries for bank workers, equivalent to the inflation rate in July. This increase will be applied to the salaries of June, and the difference between the accumulated inflation from January to July 2024 (87%) and the increments already granted in 2024 will also be paid. La Bancaria stated, 'We guarantee the application of monthly inflation indices so that bank workers do not lose against inflation, safeguarding the purchasing power of our representatives.' This increase affects all monthly gross, normal, habitual, and total remunerations, including conventional and non-conventional additional payments. To determine the exact amount, the calculation will be applied to the June income. The inflation rate in July was 4%, which is the lowest rate so far this year, according to the Indec. The accumulated inflation for the year is 87%, and the inflation rate over the past 12 months is 263.4%.
latest news.title: Salario de bancarios: de cuánto es el aumento del último acuerdo paritario de agosto

latest news.eng_title: US Inflation Rate Falls to 2.9% in July, Lowest Since 2021
latest news.summary: The inflation rate in the United States fell to 2.9% in July, the lowest since 2021, according to official data. This decrease in inflation rate has given impetus to the possibility of reducing interest rates by the Federal Reserve in September. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) fell to 2.9% in annual terms, below the 3% reported in June, and the lowest level since March 2021. The CPI was slightly below the average of economists consulted by Dow Jones, Newswires, and The Wall Street Journal. However, prices increased by 0.2% in the monthly comparison with June, when they were 0.1%. This trend corresponds to the expectations of analysts, according to the MarketWatch consensus. The underlying inflation rate, which excludes volatile products such as food and energy, was 3.2% in annual terms, also in line with market expectations and a slight decline from the previous month (3.3%). US President Joe Biden celebrated the 'progress' in the fight against inflation. 'There is still work to be done to reduce costs for American workers, but we have made real progress, with wages increasing more rapidly than prices over the past 17 months,' he highlighted in a statement. The decrease in inflation is mainly due to the decline in prices of vehicles, new and used, and to a lesser extent, clothing and fuels. Services, excluding energy, the main drivers of inflation, increased in the monthly comparison: 0.3% in July compared to 0.1% in June. The largest increases were in housing and transportation. 'The housing data are a bit disappointing and continue to be a thorn in the side of the Federal Reserve,' estimated Ryan Sweet, chief economist at Oxford Economics, in a note. 'The high prices of housing seem persistent, but with a reduction in other sectors, the Fed has a green light to reduce rates by 25 points' in its next meeting, he said. In summary, the trend of increasing prices indicates that the long-term goal of 2% in annual terms set by the Federal Reserve could be achieved. 'We do not observe a sharp drop in prices, as would be expected in the case of an economic collapse,' highlighted the economists of HFE in a note. 'Who expects to see three rate cuts by the Fed will not find anything in these data that can confirm them.' The financial markets panicked on August 5 due to an unexpected increase in interest rates by the Bank of Japan and fears of a recession in the US economy, following the release of disappointing data. US economic activity shows clear signs of deceleration after almost two years of exceptional growth, but so far, there are no signs of a potential recession despite a slight increase in unemployment last month. So far, the institution has refused to reduce interest rates, considering that it still does not have data that demonstrates that this goal will be achievable and sustainable in the long term. The United States recorded a peak inflation rate of 9.5% in terms of homologous in June 2022, after the global economy reopened after the COVID-19 pandemic. The Federal Reserve responded by increasing interest rates, which rose to a range between 5.25% and 5.50%, its highest level since the beginning of the century.
latest news.title: Inflação dos EUA cai em julho a 2,9% em ritmo anual, a menor desde 2021

latest news.summary: The AIER Business Conditions indicators for June 2024 showed mixed results, with the Leading Indicator at 54, the Roughly Coincident Indicator at 83, and the Lagging Indicator at 42. The Leading Indicator rose in seven components, fell in two, and remained neutral in three. The Roughly Coincident Indicator rose in five components and declined in one. The Lagging Indicator declined in four components, rose in one, and remained neutral in one. The substantial divergence among the three indices suggests ambiguity rather than clarity. However, the Lagging Indicator has provided the most accurate reflection of underlying economic conditions. Recent data indicates a labor market slowdown, with applications for US unemployment benefits surging to their highest point in nearly a year. The July 2024 Institute for Supply Management (ISM) manufacturing survey showed a steep drop in the employment component to 43.4, the lowest level since June 2020. The decline in industrial production and manufacturing output, as well as the drop in consumer goods production, signal weak factory output. The Empire State and Philadelphia Fed manufacturing surveys for August 2024 reinforced indications of a softening in activity, with declines in employment metrics. The consumer side shows a cautious environment, with a 0.3 percent gain in the control group's modest retail sales, and a 0.4 percent deceleration in sales excluding autos and gasoline. Recent inflation data suggest progress in the Federal Reserve's disinflation efforts, with the June Personal Consumption Expenditure (PCE) index and several months of core inflation prints roughly aligned with the Fed's 2 percent target. However, the combination of July's CPI and Producer Price Index (PPI) data imply an acceleration in the core PCE deflator on both monthly and annual bases. The activation of the Sahm Rule suggests that the United States has either entered, or is on the verge, of entering a recession.
latest news.title: Business Conditions Monthly June 2024

latest news.eng_title: US Economy: Soft or Hard Landing?
latest news.summary: The US economy's soft or hard landing has been a topic of discussion due to changing data. The S&P 500 plummeted over 6% between August 4 and 6 after the unemployment rate rose to 4.3% in July. Many analysts questioned the soft landing, but the data shows that the unemployment rate increased by 0.8 percentage points in a year, from 3.5% in July 2023 to 4.3% in July 2024. However, the Sham rule, which predicts a recession when the average unemployment rate over the last three months exceeds its 12-month minimum by 0.5 percentage points, is being followed. The average unemployment rate increase observed in the last three months is 0.53 percentage points. Although the indicator observed in July barely exceeds the rule, economist Michael Strain notes that 'when the unemployment rate goes up a little, it goes up a lot, which is why many believe the Fed should declare victory in its battle against inflation and start its cycle of rate cuts. However, this view is wrong, as it misreads the inflation perspective and the labor market.' The Fed is expected to wait for the July inflation rate, which is the key rate that follows, corresponding to the 12-month variation of the personal consumption expenditures price index, excluding fuels and food, which had registered 2.6% in May and June, the lowest since March 2021. The two presidential candidates, Trump and Harris, have positioned themselves on the economic theme, with Trump prioritizing the fight against immigration and only in point 3, 'ending inflation and making the US affordable again.' Harris has presented her economic agenda, prioritizing building an 'opportunity economy' for the middle class, and has committed to stopping the price increases of products like food and combating price speculation. She proposes a federal ban on abusive price increases in the food industry and 'new sanctions for opportunistic companies that exploit crises and break the rules.'
latest news.title: EEUU: ¿aterrizaje político o económico?

latest news.eng_title: US Inflation Falls Below 3%, Markets Rebound
latest news.summary: The US inflation rate has fallen below 3% for the first time since March 2021, with the CPI index reaching 2.9% in July. The PPI index increased by 2.2%. The publication of US retail sales data, which rose by 1% in July against an expected 0.4%, has also reduced the prospects of a near-term recession. The US unemployment claims have decreased below those of the previous week, confirming the scenario of a soft landing for the US economy. The US technology stocks, which have been battered in recent weeks, have rebounded strongly, with the Tech component of the S&P 500 rising by 7.6% over the week. The euro has appreciated by 1.03% against the US dollar over the week. The CAC 40 has gained 2.5%, the S&P 500 has risen by 3.9% (its best week of 2024) and the Nasdaq has surged by 5.3%. The German ZEW investor sentiment index has deteriorated in August, falling to 19.2, its lowest level in two years. In China, the youth unemployment rate has risen to 17.1% in July, its highest level since December 2023. The publication of earnings reports for Applied Materials, Deere, and On Holding have exceeded expectations, while Home Depot's earnings have also exceeded expectations, but the company has revised its full-year guidance downwards due to a decline in demand for home improvement projects. The market will be watching the annual symposium of central bankers in Jackson Hole, which starts on August 22, where Fed Chairman Jerome Powell will speak on Friday. The announcement of a rate cut in September seems likely, but investors will be looking for clues on the configuration of future rate cuts. The Democratic convention will take place on August 19 and 22, and the minutes of the last Fed meeting will be released on Wednesday, as well as the US PMI data on Thursday. 'We have maintained our positions and benefited from the rebound of this week,' said the article. 'A scenario similar to that of 1995, where the S&P 500 surged by 40% in the 18 months following the first rate cut by Alan Greenspan, is not excluded, even if the S&P 500 is already flirting with its highs.' The article concludes with a mix of short-term caution and medium-term optimism, citing a complex geopolitical context and nervousness among market participants.
latest news.title: Vif rebond !

latest news.eng_title: Dollar and Inflation Projections for End of Year: Experts Warn of 'Acute Recession'
latest news.summary: According to a report by FocusEconomics, the dollar will reach $1233 by the end of December 2024, and $1737.7 by the end of 2025. The inflation rate is expected to be around 234.2% by the end of 2024, surpassing the 211.4% of 2023. Experts warn that it will be difficult for the Consumer Price Index to drop below 4% by the end of the year. The report also states that the country is facing an 'acute recession in 2024' and that the economy will contract by 3.4% in 2024. As stated in the report, 'our consensus is that there will be more contractions in the second quarter, and the latest data suggests risks of a deeper contraction.' The report concludes that 'growth should remain weak in 2024 in the midst of a macroeconomic rebalancing process, with a significant fiscal adjustment and erosion of household income.'
latest news.title: Salto del dólar y la inflación y advertencia por una "aguda recesión": lo que se viene para fin de año, según estas consultoras

latest news.eng_title: US Inflation Rate Decreases to 2.9% in July, Exceeding Expectations
latest news.summary: The US Consumer Price Index (CPI) decreased by 0.1% in July to 2.9% compared to June, still above the Federal Reserve's 2% target despite high interest rates. This is the lowest inflation rate since March 2021, increasing expectations that the Federal Reserve will start cutting interest rates in September. The Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) reported that prices increased by 0.2% compared to June. The underlying inflation rate, which excludes volatile food and fuel prices, also decreased by 0.1% annually to 3.2%, and increased by 0.2% monthly. US President Joe Biden celebrated the data, but lamented that 'prices are still too high: large corporations are accumulating record profits and are not doing enough to lower prices.' Biden stated, 'Today's data shows that we are making progress in the fight against inflation and reducing costs for American households.' The BLS noted that the housing index increased in July (0.4% monthly), contributing to more than 90% of the monthly increase in prices of all items. Housing has accumulated an annual increase of 5.1%. Energy prices remained stable after decreases in the previous two periods and have accumulated a 1.1% increase in the last 12 months, while food prices increased by 0.2% in July, with an annual increase of 2.2%. The gasoline index also remained stable in July and has accumulated a 2.2% decrease in the last year. With this, inflation has accumulated four consecutive decreases since the March data, which was 3.5%. The Federal Reserve has maintained interest rates since July 2023 at a range of 5.25% to 5.5%, its highest level since 2001, after eleven increases initiated in March 2022. All eyes are now on the Fed's monthly meeting scheduled between September 17 and 18, where a first rate cut is expected. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell has insisted that he wants to see a sustained decrease in inflation and for prices to adjust around 2% before making a decision.
latest news.title: La tasa de inflación de julio en EE.UU. baja una décima hasta el 2,9 %

latest news.eng_title: Inflation cooled in July, reaching lowest level since March 2021
latest news.summary: Consumer prices rose 2.9% in July compared to a year ago, the lowest level since 2021. This marks the fifth consecutive month of slowing inflation, with prices cooling significantly from a peak of over 9%. Despite this, inflation remains 1% higher than the Fed's target rate of 2%. The latest data will ease pressure on consumers, but prices remain 20% higher than three years ago. Food prices increased 2.2% and energy prices 1.1%, while prices for rice, flour, and fish fell. However, egg prices soared 19%. The Fed may reduce interest rate cuts in September, depending on economic performance, according to Fed Chair Jerome Powell. Powell said, 'For a long time, since inflation arrived, it's been right to mainly focus on inflation. But now that inflation has come down and the labor market has indeed cooled off, we're going to be looking at both mandates. They're in much better balance.'
latest news.title: Inflation cooled in July, reaching lowest level since March 2021

news knowledge.eng_title: US Inflation Adds Optimism to Western Markets
news knowledge.summary: The US consumer inflation (CPI) for July was released on Wednesday, August 14, and it showed a 0.2% increase from June and a 2.9% increase from July 2023. This is lower than the predicted 0.2% (month-over-month) and 3.0% (year-over-year) increase. The core inflation rate also increased by 0.2% (month-over-month) and 3.2% (year-over-year), matching the predicted values. The SRI (Seasonally Adjusted Rate of Inflation) for the US without rounding was 0.155% (overall) and 0.165% (core). According to Neomarkets, the market's expectations for a decrease in the Federal Reserve's interest rates have slightly increased after the inflation reports, but there are no significant changes. The probability of four interest rate cuts by the end of the year remains, and the chances of a 0.50% interest rate cut in September are increasing. However, weak non-farm employment data could significantly increase the expectations for the rate of interest rate cuts this year, unlike inflation, which has no current impact.
news knowledge.title: Инфляция в США добавила оптимизма западным рынкам | Investing.com

news knowledge.eng_title: US Consumer Price Index Falls 0.2% in August
news knowledge.summary: According to John Kerschner, Head of US Securitised Products and Portfolio Manager at Janus Henderson Investors, both the total and core Consumer Price Index (CPI) in the US fell by 0.2% on August 14, 2024, as expected. This resulted in a year-over-year decrease in the total CPI from 3.0% in the previous month to 2.9%, and a year-over-year decrease in the core CPI from 3.3% in the previous month to 3.2%.
news knowledge.title: US-Verbraucherpreisindex von Juli

news knowledge.eng_title: This Economic Mess Is About to Hit the Fan
news knowledge.summary: The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported a 0.2% growth in headline CPI for July, up from June's -0.1%, and a 0.2% growth in core CPI, accelerating from June's 0.1%. On a year-over-year basis, headline CPI slowed from 3.0% growth to 2.9%, while core CPI printed at 3.2%, down from 3.3%. The author of the article, Guilfoyle, questions the accuracy of the report, citing examples of health insurance prices being down 0.4% month over month and down 0.6% year over year, while his own health insurer has informed him of a double-digit increase for 2025. Guilfoyle believes that the report does not change the narrative that the FOMC will cut short-term interest rates on September 18, 2024, and that the economy will slow down, potentially leading to a recession. He also notes that the market is pricing in a high probability of rate cuts, but warns that this may not be good for equities once the recession is recognized and the unemployment rate rises above 5%.
news knowledge.title: This Economic Mess Is About to Hit the Fan

news knowledge.eng_title: US Consumer Price Index Rises 0.2% in July, Easing Inflationary Pressures
news knowledge.summary: The US Consumer Price Index (CPI) rose by 0.2% in July, in line with expectations, and confirms that inflationary pressures are easing. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the CPI increased by 0.2% in July, after a 0.1% decline in June. Over the past 12 months, the CPI has risen by 2.9%, a slight decrease from the 3.0% annual increase recorded in June. Economists had predicted a 0.2% monthly increase and a 3.0% annual increase. These data follow a report published on Tuesday indicating a slight increase in production prices for the month of July. The moderation of annual CPI growth from a peak of 9.1% in June 2022 suggests that inflation is approaching the 2% target set by the Federal Reserve. The Fed must now make a decision on interest rates at its next meeting on September 17-18, with market expectations divided between a 0.5% rate cut and a 25 basis point reduction. This indecision is partly due to the fact that the unemployment rate has reached its highest level in three years, at 4.3%, in July. Despite the rise in unemployment, which has increased for four consecutive months, economists suggest that a significant deterioration in the labor market would be necessary for the central bank to consider a more aggressive 50 basis point rate cut. They attribute the rise in unemployment primarily to an increase in labor supply due to immigration, rather than an increase in layoffs. The Fed's daily reference interest rate has remained stable in the 5.25% to 5.50% range for a year, after being raised by 525 basis points in 2022 and 2023. Excluding the most volatile components, such as food and energy, the core CPI also rose by 0.2% in July, representing a slight increase from the 0.1% increase recorded in June. The core CPI over 12 months rose by 3.2% in July, representing the lowest annual increase since April 2021, and a decline from the 3.3% increase recorded in June.
news knowledge.title: Les prix à la consommation aux États-Unis ont légèrement augmenté en juillet, une baisse des taux est attendue Par Investing.com

news knowledge.eng_title: US Consumer Price Index Slows Down in July 2024
news knowledge.summary: The US Bureau of Labor Statistics announced a slowdown in the Consumer Price Index (CPI) for July 2024, with an annual increase of 2.9%, lower than expected and lower than the previous month's data. The CPI is a broad measure of the cost of goods and services. The main CPI index showed an annual increase of 2.9% in July, lower than the expected 3%, and the previous month's reading was 3%. On a monthly basis, the main inflation index rose by 0.2%, as expected, while the index fell by 0.1% in June. The core CPI (excluding food and energy) showed an annual increase of 3.2% in July, as expected, and the previous month's reading was 3.3%. On a monthly basis, the core inflation index rose by 0.2% in July, as expected, and the previous month's reading was 0.1%. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, 'the slowdown in inflation is a positive sign for the US economy.'
news knowledge.title: تراجع مؤشر أسعار المستهلكين في أميركيا لـ2.9% خلال يوليو 2024 - اليوم السابع

news knowledge.eng_title: US CPI Registers 0.2% Increase in July
news knowledge.summary: The Consumer Price Index (CPI) in the United States rose by 0.2% in July, following a 0.1% decline in June. The core CPI, which excludes food and energy, also increased by 0.2% in the seventh month of 2024, after registering 0.1% in June. Both results were in line with market expectations of a 0.2% increase. In the 12-month accumulation, the CPI in July rose 3%, the same growth recorded in June and in line with market projections. On an annual basis, the core inflation rate was 3.2%, within expectations and decelerating from the 3.3% recorded in June, according to Globo.com.
news knowledge.title: CPI dos EUA registra alta de 0,2% em julho, dentro do esperado pelo mercado

news knowledge.summary: US equity indices and the ASX 200 experienced a volatile week due to concerns of a US recession and the Reserve Bank of Australia's (RBA) hawkish stance on interest rates. The RBA's Governor Michele Bullock warned that the RBA is ready to raise rates to combat persistently high inflation. Despite this, the Australian interest rates market is skeptical about the RBA's rate hike, with a 25 basis point (bp) rate cut almost fully priced before year-end. Key economic indicators for the week ahead include the US Consumer Price Index (CPI), the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's (RBNZ) interest rate decision, and the Australian labour force report. In the US, headline inflation decreased by 0.1% month-on-month (MoM) in June, bringing the annual inflation rate down to 3.0% year-on-year (YoY). The core inflation rate for June increased by 0.1%, leading to an annual rate of 3.3%. For July, headline inflation is expected to rise by 0.2% MoM, with the annual rate holding steady at 3.0% YoY. Core inflation is also expected to increase by 0.2% MoM, with the annual core rate predicted to soften to 3.2% YoY. In China, retail sales underperformed in June, coming in at 2.0% versus the 3.3% expected. The big miss in retail sales continues to reflect sluggish domestic demand. Trade data and Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) figures have been mixed, failing to provide assurances for a more sustained recovery just yet. Overall, there are some doubts about whether China will be able to achieve its growth target of 5% in 2024, especially since China's 2Q GDP dipped to 4.7%.
news knowledge.title: Ahead of the game: 12 August 2024

news knowledge.eng_title: June 2024 CPI Report: Inflation Is Moderating, Inching Us Closer To a Rate Cut
news knowledge.summary: The June 2024 CPI report shows that inflation is moderating, with core CPI increasing by 0.1% MoM and 3.3% YoY. Shelter prices, which have been a major contributor to inflation, rose by 0.2% MoM, their smallest gain since August 2021. While prices increased in some areas, such as motor vehicle insurance and medical care, they fell in others, like airfares and used cars. The report suggests that core inflation will continue to moderate this year, and the Fed may cut interest rates as early as September. The data supports the view that the economy and labor market are becoming more balanced, which could lead to a rate cut.
news knowledge.title: June 2024 CPI Report: Inflation Is Moderating, Inching Us Closer To a Rate Cut

news knowledge.eng_title: The CPI Preview: Inflation To Keep Rising This Summer, Despite The Slowing Economy
news knowledge.summary: The June CPI inflation expectations are expected to show a rise in inflation, despite the slowing economy. The core CPI is predicted to increase by 0.2% MoM and 3.4% YoY, while the headline CPI is expected to increase by 0.1% MoM and 3.1% YoY. The annual core CPI inflation at 3.4% would match the lowest annual core inflation reading from last month, May 2024. The headline core CPI at 3.1% would be below the 3.3% level in May, but still above the cyclical low of 3% annual CPI inflation number from June 2023. The disinflationary process has stalled, and the monthly core CPI inflation readings over the last 12 months suggest that the core annual CPI inflation has either stalled at 3.4% for the next three months or it could even start rising. The InflationNowcast by Cleveland Fed predicts that June core CPI will come at 0.28%, or rounded to 0.3%, which would be an upside surprise, above the 0.2% consensus expectations. The annual CPI inflation is predicted to rise over the next 2 months, and the core CPI is predicted to rise to 3.6% by July, and the headline CPI is expected to rise to 3.2% by July. The July inflation data will be reported in August, right before the Fed's September meeting. If these predictions are correct, the Fed will not be able to cut interest rates in September, as the market currently expects.
news knowledge.title: The CPI Preview: Inflation To Keep Rising This Summer, Despite The Slowing Economy

news knowledge.eng_title: Australian private survey of inflation, June 2024: +0.3% m/m (prior +0.3%)
news knowledge.summary: The Melbourne Institute's private survey of inflation for June 2024 shows a 0.3% monthly increase, matching the previous month's rate. The year-over-year inflation rate is 3.2%, down from 3.1% in the previous month, which is the lowest in 21 months. The trimmed mean, a core measure of inflation, shows a 0.2% monthly increase and a 3% year-over-year increase, down from 0.3% and 3.2% respectively. This data comes ahead of the official quarterly CPI release from the Australian Bureau of Statistics on July 31, which may impact the Reserve Bank of Australia's decision on interest rates at its next meeting on August 5-6.
news knowledge.title: Australian private survey of inflation, June 2024: +0.3% m/m (prior +0.3%)
